# Appendix A. Proofs of main results and supporting Lemmas 

A.1. The iteration scheme. The basic approach to all our main results was outlined in Section 2.4. For each of the iterated inequalities, we start with an inequality for linear random matrices (i.e., for chaos of order $q=1$ ). The linear inequalities involve four parameters $\sigma_{R}, \sigma_{C}, v, r$ defined in Section 2.4.1. Applying these bounds conditionally on all but one of the chaos coordinates gives rise to four intermediate flattenings as shown in Figure 1. As the intermediate flattenings are themselves matrix chaoses of smaller order, the proofs proceed by induction.

The following lemma formalizes the fact, used in the induction step, that the final flattenings of intermediate flattenings coincide with the final flattenings of the original chaos.

Lemma A. $1(\sigma, v$ and $r$ of intermediate flattenings). Let $Y$ be a decoupled chaos as in (2). Given an intermediate flattening $Y_{[Z \mid R \mid C]}$, which is a chaos of order $|Z|$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\{Z \mid R \mid C\}}\right)=\max _{R^{\prime} \cup C^{\prime}=Z}\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\left[R \cup R^{\prime} \mid C \cup C^{\prime}\right]}\right\| \\
& v\left(\mathcal{A}_{\{Z \mid R \mid C\}}\right)=\max _{\substack{R^{\prime} \cup C^{\prime}=Z \\
R^{\prime} \neq \varnothing}}\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\left[R^{\prime}\left[R \cup C \cup C^{\prime}\right]\right]}\right\| \\
& r\left(\mathcal{A}_{\{Z \mid R \mid C\}}\right)=\max _{\substack{R^{\prime} \cup C^{\prime}=Z \\
R^{\prime} \cup C^{\prime} \neq \varnothing}}\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\left[R \cup R^{\prime} \mid C \cup C^{\prime}\right]}\right\| .
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. By its definition (10), the intermediate flattening $Y_{[Z \mid R \mid C]}$ is a matrix chaos with the same coefficients $\mathcal{A}_{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{q+2}}$ as $Y$, but where the $|Z|$ chaos coordinates are indexed by $i_{t}$ for $t \in Z$ and the two matrix coordinates are indexed by $\left(i_{t}: t \in R\right)$ and $\left(i_{t}: t \in C\right)$, respectively. The conclusion now follows readily from the definitions (4), (5) and (6) of the chaos parameters.

For completeness, we record here two basic relations between the chaos parameters.
Lemma A.2. For any chaos $Y$ as in (2), we have

$$
r(\mathcal{A}) \leq \sigma(\mathcal{A}) \quad \text { and } \quad r(\mathcal{A}) \leq v(\mathcal{A})
$$

Proof. In the case $q=1$, we may readily read off from the expressions in section 2.4.1 that

$$
r(Y)=\left\|\mathcal{A}_{[1,2 \mid 1,3]}\right\| \leq\left\|\mathcal{A}_{[1,2 \mid 3]}\right\| \leq \sigma(Y), \quad r(Y)=\left\|\mathcal{A}_{[1,2 \mid 1,3]}\right\| \leq\left\|\mathcal{A}_{[1 \mid 2,3]}\right\|=v(Y)
$$

where we used that $\left\|A_{i}\right\| \leq\left\|A_{i}\right\|_{F}=\left\|\operatorname{vec}\left(A_{i}\right)\right\|$ in the second inequality.
Now let $q \geq 2$, and let $\mathcal{A}_{[R \mid C]}$ be any $r$-flattening. Consider a 3 -tensor $\mathcal{B}$ whose entries are given by $\mathcal{B}_{\boldsymbol{i}_{R \cup C}, \boldsymbol{i}_{R \cup C}, \boldsymbol{i}_{C \backslash R}}=\mathcal{A}_{\boldsymbol{i}}$, where $\boldsymbol{i}=\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{q+2}\right)$ and $\boldsymbol{i}_{T}=\left(i_{t}: t \in T\right)$. Then

$$
\mathcal{B}_{[1,2 \mid 1,3]}=\mathcal{A}_{[R \mid C]}, \quad \mathcal{B}_{[1,2 \mid 3]}=\mathcal{A}_{[R \mid C \backslash R]}, \quad \mathcal{B}_{[1 \mid 2,3]}=\mathcal{A}_{\left[R \cup C \mid R^{\prime} \cup C^{\prime}\right]}
$$

As $\mathcal{A}_{\{R \mid C \backslash R\}}$ is a $\sigma$-flattening of $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{A}_{\left\{R^{\circ} \backslash C \mid R^{\circ} \cup C^{\circ}\right\}}$ is a $v$-flattening of $\mathcal{A}$, we obtain

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\{R \mid C\}}\right\|=\left\|\mathcal{B}_{\{1,2 \mid 1,3\}}\right\| \leq\left\|\mathcal{B}_{\{1,2 \mid 3\}}\right\|=\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\{R \mid C \backslash R\}}\right\| \leq \sigma(\mathcal{A}) \\
\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\{R \mid C\}}\right\|=\left\|\mathcal{B}_{\{1,2 \mid 1,3\}}\right\| \leq\left\|\mathcal{B}_{\{1 \mid 2,3\}}\right\|=\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\left\{R^{\circ} \backslash C \mid R^{\circ} \cup C^{\circ}\right\}}\right\| \leq v(\mathcal{A})
\end{gathered}
$$

by applying the inequalities for the case $q=1$ to the tensor $\mathcal{B}$.
A.2. Proof of Iterated NCK. We start by stating the linear theorem. The following result is classical, but we spell it out in a slightly more general setting than is customary.
Theorem A. 3 (Noncommutative Khintchine (NCK) inequality). Let $X=\sum_{i \in[m]} h_{i} A_{i}$, where $h_{1}, \ldots, h_{m}$ are i.i.d. copies of a centered random variable $h$ and $A_{1}, \ldots, A_{m}$ are $d_{1} \times d_{2}$ matrix coefficients (we define $d \vDash d_{1} \vee d_{2}$ ). Then we have

$$
\|h\|_{L^{1}}\left(\sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)\right) \lesssim \mathbb{E}\|X\| \lesssim\|h\|_{\psi_{2}} \log (d)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)\right)
$$

Alternatively, the upper bound remains valid if $\|h\|_{\psi_{2}}$ is replaced by $\|h\|_{L^{\log m}}$.
Proof. We begin with the lower bound. Let $\varepsilon_{i}$ be i.i.d. Rademachers variables independent of $h_{i}$, and define $\tilde{X}=\sum_{i \in[m]} \varepsilon_{i} h_{i} A_{i}$. Then $\mathbb{E}\|\tilde{X}\| \leq 2 \mathbb{E}\|X\|$ by a standard symmetrization argument [Ver18, Lemma 6.3.2]. Taking the expectation only with respect to $\varepsilon$, we can estimate

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\varepsilon}\|\tilde{X}\| \gtrsim 2\left(\mathbb{E}_{\varepsilon}\|\tilde{X}\|^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}=\left(\mathbb{E}_{\varepsilon}\left\|\tilde{X}^{\top} \tilde{X}\right\|\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}+\left(\mathbb{E}_{\varepsilon}\left\|\tilde{X} \tilde{X}^{\top}\right\|\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \geq\left\|\sum_{i} h_{i}^{2} A_{i}^{\top} A_{i}\right\|^{\frac{1}{2}}+\left\|\sum_{i} h_{i}^{2} A_{i} A_{i}^{\top}\right\|^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

where we used the Khintchine-Kahane inequality [LO94] in the first step and Jensen's inequality in the last step. As the right-hand side is a convex function of $\left(\left|h_{1}\right|, \ldots,\left|h_{m}\right|\right)$, taking the expecation and applying Jensen's inequality yields $\mathbb{E}\|X\| \gtrsim\|h\|_{L^{1}}\left(\sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)\right)$.

We now turn to the upper bound. The classical form of the noncommutative Khintchine inequality [Pis03, §9.8] (and $\operatorname{Tr}\left[|M|^{p}\right]^{1 / p} \lesssim\|M\|$ for any $d \times d$ matrix $M$ and $p \gtrsim \log d$ ) yields the upper bound in the special case that $h_{i}$ are Rademacher or standard Gaussian variables. The subgaussian upper bound then follows as $\mathbb{E}\|X\| \lesssim\|h\|_{\psi_{2}} \mathbb{E}\left\|X_{G}\right\|$, where $X_{G}=\sum_{i \in[m]} g_{i} A_{i}$ with $g_{1}, \ldots, g_{m}$ i.i.d. standard Gaussians, by the subgaussian comparison theorem [Ver18, Corollary 8.6.3].

Alternatively, by symmetrizing as in the lower bound, we can estimate

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\|X\| \leq 2 \mathbb{E}\|\tilde{X}\| & \lesssim \log (d)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left\|\sum_{i} h_{i}^{2} A_{i}^{\top} A_{i}\right\|^{\frac{1}{2}}+\mathbb{E}\left\|\sum_{i} h_{i}^{2} A_{i} A_{i}^{\top}\right\|^{\frac{1}{2}}\right) \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}\left(\max _{i \in[m]}\left|h_{i}\right|\right) \log (d)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

by applying the Rademacher form of NCK conditionally on $\boldsymbol{h}$. It remains to note that we can estimate $\mathbb{E} \max _{i \in[m]}\left|h_{i}\right| \leq\left(\mathbb{E} \max _{i \in[m]}\left|h_{i}\right|^{p}\right)^{1 / p} \leq\left(m \mathbb{E}|h|^{p}\right)^{1 / p} \lesssim\|h\|_{L^{p}}$ for $p=\log m$.

We can now complete the proof of Theorem 2.4.
Proof of Theorem 2.4. The proof is by induction on $q$. The base case $q=1$ is given by Theorem A.3. For the induction step, let $q \geq 2$. We start with the lower bound.

If we condition on $\boldsymbol{h}^{(1)}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{h}^{(q-1)}$, and treat $Y$ as a linear chaos, then applying the lower bound in NCK with respect to the randomness of $\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}$ yields (see Figure 1)

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}} \| Y\|=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}}\left\|Y_{\left[1: q \mid q+1 \mid q+2\right.}\right\| \gtrsim\|h\|_{L^{1}}\left(\left\|Y_{\left[1: q-1 \mid q, q+1 \mid q+2\right.}\right\|\right)+\left\|Y_{\left[1: q-1 \mid q+1 \mid q, q+2\right.}\right\|\right)
$$

Taking expectations and using the induction hypothesis yields

$$
\mathbb{E}\|Y\| \gtrsim_{q}\|h\|_{L^{1}}^{q}\left(\sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\{1: q-1 \mid q, q+1 \mid q+2\right\}}\right) \vee \sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\{1: q-1 \mid q+1 \mid q, q+2\right\}}\right)\right)
$$

and the conclusion follows from Lemma A.1.

The proof of the upper bound follows similarly. The NCK upper bound yields

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}}\|Y\| \lesssim\|h\|_{\psi_{2}} \log (d)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q, q+1 \mid q+2\rfloor}\right\|+\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q+1 \mid q, q+2\rfloor}\right\|\right)
$$

Taking expectations and using the induction hypothesis, we obtain

$$
\mathbb{E}\|Y\| \lesssim_{q}\|h\|_{\psi_{2}}^{q} \log (d)^{\frac{1}{2}} \log (d m+m)^{\frac{q-1}{2}}\left(\sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q, q+1 \mid q+2\rfloor}\right) \vee \sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q+1 \mid q, q+2\rfloor}\right)\right)
$$

where we used that the largest dimension of the intermediate flattenings is at most $d m$. The conclusion follows from Lemma A. 1 and using $\log (d)^{\frac{1}{2}} \log (d m+m)^{\frac{q-1}{2}} \lesssim_{q} \log (d+m)^{\frac{2}{2}}$. The identical proof yields the variant of the upper bound where $\|h\|_{\psi_{2}}$ is replaced by $\|h\|_{L^{\log m}}$.

Remark A.4. It is readily verified in the proof that the iterated NCK inequality also remains valid if $\|h\|_{\psi_{2}}$ is replaced by $C_{c}\|h\|_{L^{c \log m}}$ for any $c>0$, where $C_{c}$ is a constant that depends on $c$ only. This variant will be used below in the proofs of the iterated Rosenthal inequalities.
A.3. Proof of iterated strong NCK. We start by stating the linear theorem.

Theorem A. 5 (Strong Noncommutative Khintchine inequality). Let $X=\sum_{i \in[m]} h_{i} A_{i}$, where $h_{1}, \ldots, h_{m}$ are i.i.d. copies of a centered random variable $h$ and $A_{1}, \ldots, A_{m}$ are $d_{1} \times d_{2}$ matrix coefficients (we define $d:=d_{1} \vee d_{2}$ ). Then we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\|X\| \lesssim\|h\|_{\psi_{2}}\left(\sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)+\log (d)^{\frac{3}{2}} v(X)\right)
$$

Proof. We may estimate $\mathbb{E}\|X\| \lesssim\|h\|_{\psi_{2}} \mathbb{E}\left\|X_{G}\right\|$ as in the proof of Theorem A.3. For the Gaussian random matrix $X_{G}$, applying [BBvH23, Corollary 2.2 and Lemma 2.5] yields

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|X_{G}\right\| \lesssim \sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)+\log (d)^{\frac{3}{4}}\left(\sigma_{R}(X) \vee \sigma_{C}(X)\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} v(X)^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

and the conclusion follows by applying Young's inequality to the last term.
We can now complete the proof of Theorem 2.5.
Proof of Theorem 2.5. The proof is by induction on $q$. The base case $q=1$ is given by Theorem A.5. For the induction step, let $q \geq 2$. If we condition on $\boldsymbol{h}^{(1)}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{h}^{(q-1)}$, and treat $Y$ as a linear chaos, then applying Theorem A. 5 with respect to $\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}$ yields (see Figure 1)

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}}\|Y\| \lesssim\|h\|_{\psi_{2}}\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q, q+1 \mid q+2\rfloor}\right\|+\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q+1 \mid q, q+2\rfloor}\right\|+\log (d)^{\frac{3}{2}}\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q \mid q+1, q+2\rfloor}\right\|\right)
$$

We now take the expectation and bound the norm of each intermediate flattening. For the first two terms, we use the induction hypothesis to estimate

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q, q+1 \mid q+2\rfloor}\right\| \lesssim_{q}\|h\|_{\psi_{2}}^{q-1}\left(\sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q, q+1 \mid q+2\rfloor}\right)+\log (d m+m)^{\frac{q+1}{2}} v\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q, q+1 \mid q+2\rfloor}\right)\right) \\
& \mathbb{E}\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q+1 \mid q, q+2\rfloor}\right\| \lesssim_{q}\|h\|_{\psi_{2}}^{q-1}\left(\sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q+1 \mid q, q+2\rfloor}\right)+\log (d m+m)^{\frac{q+1}{2}} v\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q+1 \mid q, q+2\rfloor}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the last term, we use the iterated NCK inequality (Theorem 2.4) to estimate

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q \mid q+1, q+2\rfloor}\right\| \lesssim_{q}\|h\|_{\psi_{2}}^{q-1} \log \left(d^{2} \vee m+m\right)^{\frac{q-1}{2}} \sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\lfloor 1: q-1\right\rfloor q \mid q+1, q+2\rfloor}\right)
$$

Here we used that the largest dimension of the first two intermediate flattenings is at most $d m$ and of the last intermediate flattening is at most $d^{2} \vee m$. To conclude, it remains to apply Lemma A.1, and to note that all flattenings that appear in the leading terms are of $\sigma$-type and that all flattenings that appear in the terms with logarithmic factors are of $v$-type.

A.4. Proof of iterated Rosenthal inequality. We begin by stating the linear theorem. The upper bound follows from the matrix Rosenthal inequality that may be found in [JZ13, MJC+14] (see also [BvH24, Example 2.15]). We were unable to locate a reference for the lower bound.
Theorem A. 6 (Matrix Rosenthal inequality). Let $X=\sum_{i \in[m]} h_{i} A_{i}$ where $h_{1}, \ldots, h_{m}$ are i.i.d. copies of a centered unit-variance random variable $h$, and $A_{i}$ are $d_{1} \times d_{2}$ matrix coefficients (set $d:=d_{1} \vee d_{2}$ ). Let $\alpha_{c}(h):=\|h\|_{L^{c} \log (d+m)}$ for $c>0$. Then we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\|X\| \lesssim_{c} \log (d+m)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)\right)+\alpha_{c}(h) \log (d+m) r(X)
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\|X\| \gtrsim \sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)-C_{c} \alpha_{c}(h) \log (d+m)^{\frac{1}{2}} r(X)
$$

where $C_{c}$ is a constant that depends only on $c$.
Proof. The upper bound follows by applying [BvH24, Example 2.15 and Remark 2.1] with $2 p=$ $\lfloor c \log (d+m)\rfloor$ (and $\left.\operatorname{Tr}[|M|^{p}]^{1 / p} \lesssim\|M\|\right.$ for any $d \times d$ matrix $M$ and $\left.p \gtrsim \log d\right)$.

For the lower bound, we begin by estimating

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\|X\| & \gtrsim \mathbb{E}\left\|\sum_{i} h_{i}^{2} A_{i}^{\top} A_{i}\right\|^{\frac{1}{2}}+\mathbb{E}\left\|\sum_{i} h_{i}^{2} A_{i} A_{i}^{\top}\right\|^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
& \geq \sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)-\mathbb{E}\left\|\sum_{i}\left(h_{i}^{2}-1\right) A_{i}^{\top} A_{i}\right\|^{\frac{1}{2}}-\mathbb{E}\left\|\sum_{i}\left(h_{i}^{2}-1\right) A_{i} A_{i}^{\top}\right\|^{\frac{1}{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first line follows from the proof of Theorem A. 3 and the second line uses the triangle inequality. We can now apply the matrix Rosenthal upper bound to estimate

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|\sum_{i}\left(h_{i}^{2}-1\right) A_{i}^{\top} A_{i}\right\| \lesssim_{c} \log (d+m)^{\frac{1}{2}} \sigma_{R}(X) r(X)+\alpha_{c}(h)^{2} \log (d+m) r(X)^{2}
$$

where we used $\left\|\sum_{i}\left(A_{i}^{\top} A_{i}\right)^{2}\right\| \leq \sigma_{R}(X)^{2} r(X)^{2}$. Estimating the remaining term similarly, we obtain

$$
\mathbb{E}\|X\| \gtrsim \sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)-C_{c} \log (d+m)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} r(X)^{\frac{1}{2}}-C_{c} \alpha_{c}(h) \log (d+m)^{\frac{1}{2}} r(X)
$$

and the conclusion follows by Young's inequality.
We can now complete the proof of Theorem 2.6.
Proof of Theorem 2.6. We first prove the upper bound. We aim to prove by induction on $q$ that

$$
\mathbb{E}\|Y\| \lesssim_{q, c} \log (d+m)^{\frac{q}{2}} \sigma(\mathcal{A})+\alpha_{c}(h)^{q} \log (d+m)^{\frac{q+1}{2}} r(\mathcal{A})
$$

for every $c>0$, from which the conclusion follows by choosing $c=1$.
The base case $q=1$ is given by Theorem A.6. For the induction step, let $q \geq 2$. If we condition on $\boldsymbol{h}^{(1)}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{h}^{(q-1)}$, then applying Theorem A. 6 with respect to $\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}$ yields (see Figure 1)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}}\|Y\| \lesssim_{c} & \log (d+m)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left|1: q-1\right| q, q+1 \mid q+2]}\right\|+\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left|1: q-1\right| q+1 \mid q, q+2]}\right\|\right) \\
& +\alpha_{c}(h) \log (d+m)\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left|1: q-1\right| q, q+1 \mid q, q+2]}\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

Now note that the largest dimension of the intermediate flattenings that appear above is $m d$. As $\frac{c}{2} \log (m d+m) \leq c \log (d+m)$, the induction hypothesis with $c \leftarrow \frac{c}{2}$ and Lemma A. 1 yield

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left|1: q-1\right| q, q+1 \mid q+2]}\right\| \lesssim_{q, c} \log (m d+m)^{\frac{q-1}{2}} \sigma(\mathcal{A})+\alpha_{c}(h)^{q-1} \log (m d+m)^{\frac{q}{2}} r(\mathcal{A}) \\
& \mathbb{E}\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left|1: q-1\right| q+1 \mid q, q+2]}\right\| \lesssim_{q, c} \log (m d+m)^{\frac{q-1}{2}} \sigma(\mathcal{A})+\alpha_{c}(h)^{q-1} \log (m d+m)^{\frac{q}{2}} r(\mathcal{A})
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand, the iterated NCK inequality (Theorem 2.4 and Remark A.4) yields

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|\boldsymbol{Y}_{\left|1: q-1\right| q, q+1 \mid q, q+2]}\right\| \lesssim_{q, c} \alpha_{c}(h)^{q-1} \log (m d+m)^{\frac{q-1}{2}} \sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left|1: q-1\right| q, q+1 \mid q, q+2]}\right)
$$

Using again Lemma A. 1 yields $\sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left|1: q-1\right| q, q+1 \mid q, q+2]}\right) \leq r(\mathcal{A})$. The proof of the upper bound is readily concluded by combining the above estimates.

The proof of the lower bound is very similar. We first estimate
$\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}} \| Y\left\|\gtrsim\left\|Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q, q+1\|q+2\|}\right\|+\left\|Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q+1\|q, q+2\|}\right\|-C_{c} \alpha_{c}(h) \log (d+m)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left\|Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q, q+1\|q, q+2\|}\right\|$ using Theorem A.6. The proof is concluded by lower bounding the expectation of the first two terms using the induction hypothesis and Lemma A.1, and bounding the expectation of the last term by the iterated NCK inequality as in the upper bound.
A.5. Proof of iterated strong matrix Rosenthal inequality. We first state the linear theorem.

Theorem A. 7 (Strong matrix Rosenthal inequality). Let $X=\sum_{i \in[m]} h_{i} A_{i}$ where $h_{1}, \ldots, h_{m}$ are i.i.d. copies of a centered unit-variance random variable $h$, and $A_{i}$ are $d_{1} \times d_{2}$ matrix coefficients (set $d:=d_{1} \vee d_{2}$ ). Let $\alpha_{c}(h):=\|h\|_{L^{c} \log (d+m)}$ for $c>0$. Then we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\|X\| \lesssim_{c} \sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)+\alpha_{c}(h) \log (d+m)^{2} v(X)
$$

Proof. Combining [BvH24, Theorem 2.9 and Remark 2.1] and [BBvH23, Theorem 2.7 and Lemma 2.5] with $2 p=\lfloor c \log (d+m)\rfloor\left(\right.$ and $\left.\operatorname{Tr}[|M|^{p}]^{1 / p} \lesssim\|M|\right]$ for any $d \times d$ matrix $M$ and $\left.p \gtrsim \log d\right)$ yields

$$
\mathbb{E}\|X\| \lesssim_{c} \sigma_{R}(X)+\sigma_{C}(X)+\log (d+m)^{\frac{2}{2}}\left(\sigma_{R}(X) \vee \sigma_{C}(X)\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} v(X)^{\frac{1}{2}}+\alpha_{c}(h) \log (d+m)^{2} r(X)
$$

The conclusion follows using Young's inequality and as $r(X) \leq v(X)$ (Lemma A.2).
We can now complete the proof of Theorem 2.7.
Proof of Theorem 2.7. We aim to prove by induction on $q$ that

$$
\mathbb{E}\|Y\| \lesssim_{q, c} \sigma(\mathcal{A})+\alpha_{c}(h)^{q} \log (d+m)^{\frac{q+2}{2}} v(\mathcal{A})
$$

for every $c>0$, from which the conclusion follows by choosing $c=1$.
The base case $q=1$ is given by Theorem A.7. For the induction step, let $q \geq 2$. If we condition on $\boldsymbol{h}^{(1)}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{h}^{(q-1)}$, then applying Theorem A. 7 with respect to $\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}$ yields (see Figure 1)

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{h}^{(q)}} \| Y\left\|_{\left.\lesssim_{c}\right\| Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q, q+1\|q+2\|}\right\|+\left\|Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q+1\|q, q+2\|}\right\|+\alpha_{c}(h) \log (d+m)^{2}\left\|Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q\|q+1, q+2\|}\right\|
$$

As in the proof of Theorem 2.6, the induction hypothesis with $c \leftarrow \frac{c}{2}$ and Lemma A. 1 yield

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left\|Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q, q+1\|q+2\|}\right\| \lesssim_{q, c} \sigma(\mathcal{A})+\alpha_{c}(h)^{q-1} \log (m d+m)^{\frac{q+2}{2}} v(\mathcal{A}) \\
& \mathbb{E}\left\|Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q+1\|q, q+2\|}\right\| \lesssim_{q, c} \sigma(\mathcal{A})+\alpha_{c}(h)^{q-1} \log (m d+m)^{\frac{q+2}{2}} v(\mathcal{A})
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand, the iterated NCK inequality (Theorem 2.4 and Remark A.4) yields

$$
\mathbb{E}\left\|Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q\|q+1, q+2\|}\right\| \lesssim_{q, c} \alpha_{c}(h)^{q-1} \log (m d+m)^{\frac{q-1}{2}} \sigma\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q\|q+1, q+2\|}\right)
$$

Using again Lemma A. 1 yields $\sigma\left(Y_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q\|q+1, q+2\|}\right) \leq v(\mathcal{A})$, concluding the proof.
Remark A.8. In the strong matrix Rosenthal inequality that appears in the proof of Theorem A.7, the distributional parameter $\alpha_{c}(h)$ appears only in the term that is controlled by $r(X)$. We simplified this inequality by estimating $r(X) \leq v(X)$. This simplification can be lossy when $r(X) \ll v(X)$, particularly in sparse situations when the parameter $\alpha_{c}(h)$ may be very large.

One may hope that exploiting the sharper form of the strong matrix Rosenthal inequality could give rise to an improved form of Theorem 2.7 where the distributional parameter appears only in a term controlled by $r(\mathcal{A})$. It is not possible to iterate the sharper inequality, however, as it is not true in general that $r\left(\mathcal{A}_{\left\|1: q-1\right\| q\|q+1, q+2\|}\right)$ can be controlled by $r(\mathcal{A})$.

It is possible to obtain improved chaos inequalities by introducing additional chaos parameters that control such terms, but we do not at present know of a compelling application of such inequalities.

A.6. Norms of flattenings. We first consider chaoses of combinatorial type.
Proof of Proposition 3.4. Given a chaos of combinatorial type (13), its flattenings (3) are

$$
\mathcal{A}_{\lceil R \mid C\rceil}=\sum_{\mathbf{s} \in\left[S_{1}\right] \times \cdots \times\left[S_{p}\right]}\left(\bigotimes_{t \in R} e_{I_{t}(\mathbf{s})}\right) \otimes\left(\bigotimes_{t \in C} e_{I_{t}(\mathbf{s})}^{\top}\right)
$$

Using the natural identification $e_{I_{t}(\mathbf{s})} \simeq e_{I_{t}(\mathbf{s})_{1}} \otimes \cdots \otimes e_{I_{t}(\mathbf{s})_{\left|I_{t}\right|}}$ and permuting the order of tensor products (which corresponds to reordering rows and columns), we obtain

$$
\mathcal{A}_{\lceil R \mid C\rceil} \simeq \sum_{\mathbf{s} \in\left[S_{1}\right] \times \cdots \times\left[S_{p}\right]} \bigotimes_{u \in[p]}\left(e_{s_{u}}^{\otimes \mu_{u}} \otimes\left(e_{s_{u}}^{\top}\right)^{\otimes \nu_{u}}\right)
$$

where $\mu_{u}$ and $\nu_{u}$ denote the number of times the summation index $s_{u}$ appears as a row or column index respectively in the tensor product. Distributivity yields

$$
\mathcal{A}_{\lceil R \mid C\rceil} \simeq \bigotimes_{u \in[p]} B_{u} \quad \text { with } \quad B_{u}=\sum_{s \in\left[S_{u}\right]}\left(e_{s}^{\otimes \mu_{u}} \otimes\left(e_{s}^{\top}\right)^{\otimes \nu_{u}}\right)
$$

In particular, we have

$$
\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\lceil R \mid C\rceil}\right\|=\prod_{u \in[p]}\left\|B_{u}\right\|
$$

Now note that, by definition, $\mu_{u}=0$ if and only if $u \in \mathcal{R}^{c}$, and $\nu_{u}=0$ if and only if $u \in \mathcal{C}^{c}$. We can therefore compute using (18) that $\left\|B_{u}\right\|=\left(\sqrt{S_{u}}\right)^{\mathbf{1}_{u \in \mathcal{R}^{c}+\mathbf{1}_{u \in \mathcal{C}^{c}}}}$, and the conclusion follows.

To proceed, we need the following.
Lemma A.9. If $M, M^{\prime}$ are (real) matrices so that $\left|M_{i, j}\right| \leq M_{i, j}^{\prime}$ for all $i, j$, then $\|M\| \leq\left\|M^{\prime}\right\|$.
Proof. Note that $\|M\|=\sup _{\|x\|=\|y\|=1} \sum_{i, j} x_{i} M_{i, j} x_{j} \leq \sup _{\|x\|=\|y\|=1} \sum_{i, j}\left|x_{i}\right|\left|M_{i, j}\right|\left|x_{j}\right| \leq\left\|M^{\prime}\right\|$.
We can now extend the bound to chaoses of nearly combinatorial type.
Proof of Proposition 3.7. Given a chaos of nearly combinatorial type, following the same steps as in the proof of Proposition 3.4, we obtain an analogue of (33):

$$
\mathcal{A}_{\lceil R \mid C\rceil}^{f} \simeq \sum_{\mathbf{s}} f(\mathbf{s}) \bigotimes_{u \in[p]}\left(e_{s_{u}}^{\otimes \mu_{u}} \otimes\left(e_{s_{u}}^{\top}\right)^{\otimes \nu_{u}}\right)
$$

Define the associated flattening of combinatorial type by replacing $f \leftarrow 1$ :

$$
\mathcal{A}_{\lceil R \mid C\rceil} \simeq \sum_{\mathbf{s}} \bigotimes_{u \in[p]}\left(e_{s_{u}}^{\otimes \mu_{u}} \otimes\left(e_{s_{u}}^{\top}\right)^{\otimes \nu_{u}}\right)
$$

Lemma A. 9 yields $\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\lceil R \mid C\rceil}^{f}\right\| \leq\|f\|_{\infty}\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\lceil R \mid C\rceil}\right\|$, and we conclude using Proposition 3.4.
Remark A. 10 (Analogue of Proposition 3.7 for intermediate flattenings). Consider a chaos $Y$ of nearly combinatorial type, and let $Y_{\lceil Z \mid R \mid C\rceil}$ be an intermediate flattening as in (10). Then

$$
Y_{\lceil Z \mid R \mid C\rceil} \simeq \sum_{\mathbf{s}} f(\mathbf{s})\left(\prod_{t \in Z} h_{I_{t}(s)}^{(t)}\right) \bigotimes_{u \in[p]}\left(e_{s_{u}}^{\otimes \mu_{u}} \otimes\left(e_{s_{u}}^{\top}\right)^{\otimes \nu_{u}}\right)
$$

If $h$ is uniformly bounded, then we can argue as in the proof of Proposition 3.7 that

$$
\left\|Y_{\lceil Z \mid R \mid C\rceil}\right\| \leq\|f\|_{\infty}\|h\|_{\infty}^{|Z|}\left\|\mathcal{A}_{\lceil R \mid C\rceil}\right\| \leq\|f\|_{\infty}\|h\|_{\infty}^{|Z|}\left(\prod_{u \in \mathcal{R}^{c}} \sqrt{S_{u}}\right)\left(\prod_{u \in \mathcal{C}^{c}} \sqrt{S_{u}}\right)
$$

where we used Proposition 3.4 in the second inequality.

Note that while the definitions of the parameters $\sigma(\mathcal{A}), v(\mathcal{A}), r(\mathcal{A})$ only involved flattenings $\mathcal{A}_{[R \mid C]}$ with $R \cup C=[q+2]$, this need not be the case when considering intermediate flattenings. This is not a problem, as neither the definitions nor the arguments in the proof rely on this assumption.
A.7. Menger's theorem. The following classical result is used in Section 4.3.

Theorem A. 11 (Menger's theorem, [G0̄2]). Let $G$ be a finite graph and $U, V \subseteq V(G)$ be two subsets of vertices. We say $S$ is a $U-V$ vertex separator if all paths from $U$ to $V$ pass through $S$. Then the minimal size of a $U-V$ vertex separator equals the maximal number of vertex-disjoint paths from $U$ to $V$ that contain exactly one point in $U$ and one point in $V$.

It should be noted that $U, V$ need not be disjoint in Theorem A.11. In this case, any vertex in $U \cap V$ defines a path from $U$ to $V$ of length one. Such a point/path must therefore be contained in any vertex separator, and in any maximal collection of disjoint paths as in the theorem statement.

abstract:
Matrix concentration inequalities and their recently discovered sharp
counterparts provide powerful tools to bound the spectrum of random matrices
whose entries are linear functions of independent random variables. However, in
many applications in theoretical computer science and in other areas one
encounters more general random matrix models, called matrix chaoses, whose
entries are polynomials of independent random variables. Such models have often
been studied on a case-by-case basis using ad-hoc methods that can yield
suboptimal dimensional factors.
  In this paper we provide general matrix concentration inequalities for matrix
chaoses, which enable the treatment of such models in a systematic manner.
These inequalities are expressed in terms of flattenings of the coefficients of
the matrix chaos. We further identify a special family of matrix chaoses of
combinatorial type for which the flattening parameters can be computed
mechanically by a simple rule. This allows us to provide a unified treatment of
and improved bounds for matrix chaoses that arise in a variety of applications,
including graph matrices, Khatri-Rao matrices, and matrices that arise in
average case analysis of the sum-of-squares hierarchy.
